attack_path.result: Identified AD ports, enumerated domain users, discovered DEV share without access
attack_path.mitigation: Apply least privilege; restrict enumdomusers; properly configure SMB share permissions

attack_path.technique: BloodHound analysis and bloodyAD ACL abuse
attack_path.result: Added levi.james to DEVELOPERS group, gained access to DEV share
attack_path.mitigation: Restrict ACLs on sensitive groups; implement group policies to prevent unauthorized group membership changes

attack_path.technique: SMB file download and KeePass 4 brute force
attack_path.result: Recovered and cracked recovery.kdbx password, obtained stored credentials
attack_path.mitigation: Avoid storing sensitive files on accessible shares; enforce strong master passwords and key files

attack_path.result: Found valid credentials for ant.edwards / Antman2025!
attack_path.mitigation: Enforce account lockouts; require complex passwords

attack_path.result: Ant.edwards has GenericAll over adam.silver user object
attack_path.mitigation: Audit and remediate excessive ACL permissions

attack_path.result: Reset and enabled adam.silver account
attack_path.mitigation: Restrict who can reset passwords and enable accounts; monitor changes

attack_path.technique: Evil-WinRM session and backup file enumeration
attack_path.result: Downloaded backup containing steph.cooper credentials
attack_path.mitigation: Secure backup directories; encrypt sensitive files; audit backup contents

attack_path.technique: DPAPI blob extraction and decryption using impacket-dpapi
attack_path.result: Recovered steph.cooper_adm credentials
attack_path.mitigation: Enforce strong passwords; protect DPAPI master keys; segment networks

attack_path.technique: BloodHound analysis and impacket-secretsdump DCSync attack
attack_path.result: Dumped NTLM hashes for all domain accounts including Administrator
attack_path.mitigation: Implement tiered admin model; restrict DCSync permissions; monitor for DCSync activity

attack_path.result: Gained Administrator shell and obtained root.txt
attack_path.mitigation: Use Credential Guard; prevent pass-the-hash; monitor admin logins

attack_path.result: Discovered open ports 22/SSH and 80/HTTP. Web service running Nginx 1.18.0.
Identified AI-based app allowing user registration and upload of `.h5` model and `requirements.txt` files.
Uploaded a malicious `.h5` model using `Lambda` with embedded `os.system()` call. Triggering 'View Predictions' led to reverse shell as `app`.
Found `users.db` containing hashed credentials for user `gael`.
Cracked MD5 hash for `gael` and recovered password: `mattp005numbertwo`.
Logged into system via SSH as `gael` using cracked credentials.
Located backup file at `/var/backups/backrest_backup.tar.gz` readable by `gael` (sysadm group).
Extracted base64-encoded Bcrypt hash from config file in backup: `$2a$10$cV...`.
Cracked password: `!@#$%^` for user `backrest_root`.
Forwarded local port 9898 to access local-only service (`localhost:9898`).
Logged into local service as `backrest_root:!@#$%^`, gained command execution and root shell.
Initialized restic backup to attacker's rest-server, including `/root` directory.
Restored `/root` directory locally, extracted `root.txt` and root's private SSH key.
Logged in directly as `root` using extracted private key.
Identified open ports (22, 80), virtual host redirection to academy.htb, and various web directories/files: /home.php, /admin.php, /login.php, /register.php, /config.php.
Registered a new user account with administrative privileges (roleid=1) on register.php.
Logged into admin.php, disclosing the 'dev-staging.academy.htb' virtual host.

attack_path.technique: Virtual Host Access, Error Message Analysis
attack_path.result: Accessed dev-staging.academy.htb, revealing it's a Laravel application in debug mode and disclosing the `APP_KEY`.
Used `exploit/unix/http/laravel_token_unserialize_exec` with the extracted `APP_KEY` to gain a reverse shell as `www-data`.
Found database credentials (`DB_PASSWORD=mySup3rP4s5w0rd!!`) in the `.env` file.
Obtained a list of system users: egre55, mrb3n, cry0l1t3, 21y4d, ch4p, g0blin.
Tested `mySup3rP4s5w0rd!!` against enumerated users via SSH, finding valid credentials for `cry0l1t3`.
Logged in as `cry0l1t3` and identified membership in the `adm` group, indicating access to logs.
Used `aureport --tty` on `/var/log/audit/audit.log` to discover password `mrb3n_Ac@d3my!` for user `mrb3n`.

attack_path.technique: SSH Login, Sudo Privilege Escalation (GTFOBins - composer)
attack_path.result: Logged in as `mrb3n`, discovered `sudo` privileges for `/usr/bin/composer`, and used a GTFOBins payload to escalate to `root`.
Identified open ports (21/ftp, 22/ssh, 80/http) and discovered a disallowed entry `/admin-dir` in `robots.txt`.
Discovered `credentials.txt` and `contacts.txt` within the `/admin-dir`.
Obtained FTP credentials (`ftpuser:%n?4Wz}R$tTF7`), internal mail credentials, and WordPress credentials from `credentials.txt`.
Successfully logged into the FTP service and downloaded `dump.sql` and `html.tar.gz`.

Extracted `index.php` from `html.tar.gz` revealing database credentials (`waldo:&<h5b~yK3F#{PaPB&dA}{H>`). Further analysis of `db_admin.php` within `utility-scripts` revealed other credentials (`waldo:Wh3r3_1s_w4ld0?`).
Discovered `info.php`, `phptest.php`, and `adminer.php` within the `/utility-scripts` directory.
Identified Adminer 4.6.2 running on `/utility-scripts/adminer.php`, which is vulnerable to arbitrary file read via remote MySQL database connection.
Set up a local MySQL database with a new user and database, and established a `socat` tunnel to expose MySQL to the target.
Used the Adminer vulnerability to read `/var/www/html/index.php` due to `open_basedir` restrictions, discovering valid SSH credentials for `waldo` (`waldo:&<h5b~yK3F#{PaPB&dA}{H>`).
Successfully logged into the target machine as user `waldo` via SSH.
Discovered that user `waldo` can run `/opt/scripts/admin_tasks.sh` with `SETENV` enabled as root.
Analyzed `admin_tasks.sh` and identified that option 6 calls `/opt/scripts/backup.py`, a script writable by `waldo` that imports `shutil`.
Created a malicious `shutil.py` in `/dev/shm` containing a reverse shell payload and set the `PYTHONPATH` environment variable to `/dev/shm`.
Executed `sudo PYTHONPATH="/dev/shm" /opt/scripts/admin_tasks.sh` with option 6, triggering the malicious `shutil.py` and gaining a root shell.
Discovered open port 23/tcp running HP JetDirect Telnet service.
Confirmed HP JetDirect service is running by grabbing banner via Netcat.
Identified potential exploits for HP JetDirect including SNMP password disclosure.
Discovered open SNMP port (161/udp) and additional service on 2002/udp.
Retrieved printer name and extracted encoded admin password via OID `1.3.6.1.4.1.11.2.3.9.1.1.13.0`.
Decoded hex-encoded password to plaintext `P@ssw0rd@123!!123`.
Authenticated to Telnet as user `lp` and accessed the JetDirect admin interface.
Uploaded and executed a reverse shell using `exec` command, gaining shell access as user `lp`.
Read contents of `user.txt` after gaining shell access.
Identified CUPS service running on localhost port 631 (IPP).
Forwarded localhost:631 from target to attacker's machine via chisel reverse proxy.
Accessed CUPS administration panel on `localhost:631/admin` revealing error log viewing functionality.
Modified CUPS `ErrorLog` path to `/etc/shadow` using `cupsctl`, enabling local file read.
Retrieved `/etc/shadow` and `/root/root.txt` via CUPS log view endpoint.
Discovered open ports 22/SSH and 80/HTTP. Web server running Apache 2.4.6 with PHP 5.4.16.
Confirmed CMS is Drupal version 7.56.
Identified CVE-2018-7600 (Drupalgeddon2) RCE vulnerability.
Successfully executed RCE and uploaded a PHP web shell (`shell.php`).
Obtained limited shell as user `apache`.
Read `/var/www/html/sites/default/settings.php` and extracted MySQL credentials: `drupaluser:CQHEy@9M*m23gBVj`.
Queried `users` table and retrieved Drupal hash for user `brucetherealadmin`.
Cracked password hash, revealing credentials: `brucetherealadmin:booboo`.
Successfully logged in as `brucetherealadmin` via SSH.
User can run `sudo /usr/bin/snap install *` with NOPASSWD and SETENV.
Crafted malicious Snap package with install hook to SUID `/bin/bash` and executed it using Snap install.
Executed `./bash -p` and obtained root shell (euid=0).
Discovered open ports 22/SSH (OpenSSH 8.2p1) and 80/HTTP (uvicorn, likely FastAPI backend).
Identified FastAPI endpoints at `/api`, `/api/v1`, `/api/v1/user`, and `/api/v1/admin`; `/docs` requires authentication.
Found user ID 1 (`admin@htb.local`) and is_superuser: true via `/api/v1/user` endpoint enumeration.
Created user `b0d@haha.com` with password `Password` using `/api/v1/user/signup`.
Obtained JWT access token via `/api/v1/user/login`, enabling access to authenticated routes like `/docs`.
Accessed Swagger interface revealing `/api/v1/user/updatepass` accepting GUID and new password.
Used known admin GUID to reset password to `Password1`, confirmed success via HTTP 201 response.
Retrieved JWT with `is_superuser: true` via `/api/v1/user/login`.

attack_path.technique: Command Execution Attempt (Missing JWT Debug Flag)
attack_path.result: Discovered `/api/v1/admin/exec/{command}` required additional `debug: true` claim in JWT.
Enumerated internal files such as `/proc/self/environ`, `/home/htb/uhc/app/main.py`, and `config.py`.
Extracted JWT secret key `SuperSecretSigningKey-HTB` from `app/core/config.py`.
Forged new JWT with `is_superuser: true` and `debug: true` using jwt.io and secret key.
Sent base64-encoded reverse shell payload to `/api/v1/admin/exec/`, gaining shell as `htb` user.
Found probable root password `Tr0ub4dor&3` mistakenly typed as a username.
Used `su -` with password `Tr0ub4dor&3` to gain root shell.
Discovered open ports: 22 (SSH), 53 (DNS - ISC BIND), 80 (Apache).
Successfully transferred bank.htb zone using `dig axfr`; identified subdomains: bank.htb, ns.bank.htb, www.bank.htb.
Added subdomains to /etc/hosts to enable proper name resolution.
Modified HTTP 302 responses to 200 OK; bypassed authentication to explore the site directly.
Uploaded a PHP web shell disguised as an image; bypassed file type and extension checks.

attack_path.technique: Remote Command Execution via Uploaded Web Shell
attack_path.result: Triggered reverse shell using netcat payload; gained shell as `www-data` user.
Downloaded and examined .acc files; found cleartext credentials due to encryption failure.
Used leaked credentials `!##HTBB4nkP4ssw0rd!##` to access authenticated features like upload.
Found and executed `/var/htb/bin/emergency`, which instantly granted root shell.
Modified `/etc/passwd` to create a new root user with password `lucab0dd`; logged in via `su` as root.
Identified port 80 open; running Apache 2.4.18 on Ubuntu.
Discovered phpbash at /dev/phpbash.php; gained command execution as www-data.
Uploaded and executed PHP reverse shell via web; gained interactive shell as www-data.
Found www-data can run any command as scriptmanager without password.
Executed `sudo -u scriptmanager /bin/bash`; gained shell as scriptmanager.
Modified /scripts/test.py with reverse shell payload; triggered by root cronjob.

attack_path.technique: Reverse Shell Catch from Cron Execution
attack_path.result: Received reverse shell from root via cron; gained root shell.
Identified multiple services including Apache (443), SMTP (25), Webmin (10000), and Elastix/FreePBX.
Exploited LFI to read /etc/amportal.conf and retrieved multiple passwords including jEhdIekWmdjE.
Logged in as root using discovered password jEhdIekWmdjE. (Unintended path)

attack_path.technique: SMTP Mailbox Web Shell Injection + LFI
attack_path.result: Sent PHP payload to asterisk@localhost via SMTP and used LFI to execute it; gained shell as asterisk.
Enumerated SIP extension 233 and executed reverse shell; gained shell as asterisk.
Injected reverse shell payload into User-Agent header; gained root shell. (Unintended path)
Ran `sudo nmap --interactive`, used `!sh` to spawn root shell.
Identified open ports: 21 (FTP), 22 (SSH), and 80 (HTTP). Detected WordPress site and /plugins directory hosting .jar files.
Discovered /plugins directory with BlockyCore.jar containing hardcoded credentials.
Extracted SQL credentials: root:8YsqfCTnvxAUeduzjNSXe22.

attack_path.technique: SSH Login Using Password from JAR
attack_path.result: Successfully logged in as notch using password 8YsqfCTnvxAUeduzjNSXe22.
Logged in via FTP as notch, uploaded SSH key to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys, and gained shell.

attack_path.technique: WordPress Web Shell via Theme Editor
attack_path.result: Logged into WordPress admin using wordpress:kWuvW2SYsABmzywYRdoD, edited theme file to insert web shell, gained www-data shell.

attack_path.technique: Read phpMyAdmin Config + su to notch
attack_path.result: Used web shell to read /etc/phpmyadmin/config-db.php revealing phpmyadmin:8YsqfCTnvxAUeduzjNSXe22, reused this password to `su - notch`.
Used `sudo -l` to discover full sudo access; ran `sudo su -` to gain root shell.
Discovered open port 80 running Apache with Blunder CMS v3.9.2, directories /about, /admin, /usb, and files like todo.txt indicating username 'fergus'.

attack_path.technique: CMS Authentication Bypass via X-Forwarded-For Header
attack_path.result: By rotating X-Forwarded-For headers to bypass brute-force protection, successfully brute forced user 'fergus' password: RolandDeschain.

attack_path.technique: Authenticated File Upload with Directory Traversal
attack_path.result: Uploaded PHP reverse shell disguised as an image via vulnerable upload endpoint using directory traversal to place shell in /bl-content/tmp/. Uploaded .htaccess file to enable PHP execution of .png files.
Accessed uploaded shell.png to obtain a shell as www-data user.
Read Bludit flat-file database files to extract user hashes, including an unsalted hash for 'hugo'.
Cracked unsalted hash for user 'hugo' to plaintext password: Password120.
Logged in as hugo with cracked password.
Found sudo permission allowing bash as any user except root (ALL, !root) /bin/bash.
Exploited sudo flaw by running 'sudo -u#-1 /bin/bash' to bypass root exclusion, gained root shell.
Discovered open ports 22 (SSH) and 80 (HTTP) hosting 'Bounty Hunters' web app.
Exploited XXE vulnerability in Bounty Report System to read arbitrary files including 'db.php'.
Extracted database credentials from 'db.php': admin:m19RoAU0hP41A1sTsq6K.
SSH login successful as user 'development' using database password.
Discovered NOPASSWD sudo permission to run '/usr/bin/python3.8 /opt/skytrain_inc/ticketValidator.py' as root.

attack_path.technique: Arbitrary Code Execution via Unsafe eval() in Python Script
attack_path.result: Crafted malicious ticket file to execute arbitrary commands as root via eval() in ticketValidator.py.
Obtained root shell; full system compromise achieved.
Discovered open ports 22 (SSH) and 80 (HTTP) hosting Joomla! 3.8.8; found hidden comment pointing to secret.txt.

attack_path.technique: Information Disclosure via Hidden Comment and File Access
attack_path.result: Retrieved secret.txt containing base64 encoded password 'Curling2018!#'.

attack_path.technique: Brute-Force Joomla! Admin Login with cewl-generated wordlist
attack_path.result: Discovered valid credentials: Floris:Curling2018!# via wfuzz and HTTP 303 redirect detection.

attack_path.technique: Web Shell Upload via Joomla! Template Editor
attack_path.result: Injected PHP code '<?php system($_REQUEST['cmd']); ?>' into protostar template to get remote code execution as www-data.

attack_path.technique: Local File Discovery and Steganography Analysis
attack_path.result: Found password_backup file readable by www-data; extracted nested compressed data revealing password: '5d<wdCbdZu)|hChXll'.
SSH access granted for user floris with cracked password.

attack_path.technique: Cron Job Analysis with Process Monitoring (pspy64)
attack_path.result: Discovered root cron job running 'curl -K /home/floris/admin-area/input' and overwriting input with /root/default.txt.
Modified /home/floris/admin-area/input to instruct curl to overwrite /etc/sudoers with attacker-controlled sudoers_payload, granting floris sudo privileges.
Used new sudo privileges to execute 'sudo su -' and obtained root shell.
Discovered ports 22 (SSH), 80 (nginx with helpdesk.delivery.htb hosting osTicket), and 8065 (Mattermost v5.30.0).

attack_path.technique: Email Verification Bypass via osTicket Email Integration
attack_path.result: Registered Mattermost account with testuser@delivery.htb. Verification email routed to osTicket ticket comments, revealing verification token.

attack_path.technique: Account Activation Using osTicket Email Contents
attack_path.result: Activated Mattermost account using the extracted token from the osTicket system.
Discovered credentials maildeliverer:Youve_G0t_Mail! and hints for password reuse and privilege escalation.
Successfully logged in as maildeliverer via SSH.

attack_path.technique: Password Spraying and sucrack for Privilege Escalation
attack_path.result: Compiled sucrack on target and cracked root password: PleaseSubscribe!21; gained root shell via su -.

attack_path.technique: Locating and Using Mattermost Database Credentials
attack_path.result: Found /opt/mattermost/config/config.json with database credentials mmuser:Crack_The_MM_Admin_PW.

attack_path.technique: MySQL Access and User Hash Dumping
attack_path.result: Logged into MariaDB, dumped users and bcrypt password hashes from Mattermost database.

attack_path.technique: Cracking bcrypt Hashes with john and Password List
attack_path.result: Cracked bcrypt hash revealing root password: PleaseSubscribe!21; used to gain root shell.
Discovered open ports 22 (SSH OpenSSH 8.2p1), 80 (Apache httpd 2.4.41), and 8089 (Splunkd HTTP). Identified virtual host doctors.htb with web application endpoints.

attack_path.technique: Command Injection via curl in URL Submission
attack_path.result: Injected shell commands via URL parameter processed by curl backend. Used IFS to bypass space filters and staged reverse shell download and execution, gaining shell as web user.

attack_path.technique: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) in Post Titles
attack_path.result: Submitted {{7*7}} in title, confirming SSTI with Jinja2 template engine. Exploited SSTI with Jinja2 payload to achieve RCE and obtain web user shell.

attack_path.technique: Local Enumeration and Log File Analysis
attack_path.result: Discovered web user in adm group with read access to /var/log/apache2/backup containing password reset POST request revealing password 'Guitar123'.

attack_path.technique: User Login via su with Discovered Password
attack_path.result: Used password 'Guitar123' to switch user to shaun (su - shaun).
Logged into Splunk web interface on port 8089 using shaun credentials. Identified Splunk version 8.0.5.

attack_path.technique: Remote Code Execution via SplunkWhisperer2 Exploit
attack_path.result: Deployed malicious Splunk app bundle using SplunkWhisperer2 exploit to achieve root shell execution.

attack_path.technique: Initial Nmap Enumeration and OS Identification
attack_path.result: Discovered unusual SSH banner 'Banana Studio' indicating Android OS. Identified exposed ES File Explorer HTTP server on port 42135 and filtered port 5555 likely running Android Debug Bridge (ADB).

attack_path.technique: Arbitrary File Read Exploit on ES File Explorer (CVE-2019-6447)
attack_path.result: Exploited ES File Explorer vulnerability to list and download arbitrary files. Retrieved creds.jpg containing credentials kristi:Kr1sT!5h@Rp3xPl0r3!.
Logged into SSH service on port 2222 as user kristi, confirmed by shell uid=10076(u0_a76).

attack_path.technique: Local Port Analysis and SSH Tunneling to Access ADB
attack_path.result: Identified local ADB service on port 5555 via ss command. Created SSH tunnel forwarding local port 5555 to device's localhost:5555.

attack_path.technique: ADB Connection and Privilege Escalation via adb root Command
attack_path.result: Connected adb client to forwarded port and successfully restarted adbd as root, gaining root shell access (uid=0).
Discovered FTP (vsftpd 3.0.3), SSH, DNS (BIND), Apache HTTP/HTTPS, Samba shares with varying permissions; DNS zone transfer revealed multiple subdomains.
Enumerated Samba shares with smbmap and smbclient; retrieved creds.txt from general share containing admin:WORKWORKHhallelujah@#.
Performed zone transfer on friendzone.red and friendzoneportal.red; discovered multiple subdomains including administrator1.friendzone.red and admin.friendzoneportal.red.
Logged into administrator1.friendzone.red with harvested credentials; discovered Local File Inclusion vulnerability with include($_GET['pagename'].'.php') pattern.

attack_path.technique: LFI to RCE via Upload on Writable Samba Share
attack_path.result: Uploaded PHP reverse shell to writable Development Samba share mapped to /etc/Development; triggered RCE via LFI including uploaded shell, gained www-data shell.
Found mysql_data.conf in web root containing db_user=friend and db_pass=Agpyu12!0.213$; used these credentials to SSH as friend user.

attack_path.technique: Privilege Escalation via World-Writable Python Library and Cron Job
attack_path.result: Identified root-owned cron job running /opt/server_admin/reporter.py importing world-writable /usr/lib/python2.7/os.py; modified os.py to include reverse shell payload; waited for cron to execute and got root shell.
Discovered SSH (22), SMB (139/445), HTTP Nginx on port 9999, and Node-RED on port 1880.

attack_path.technique: Web Directory Enumeration and Client-Side Authentication Bypass
attack_path.result: Found /admin login with client-side only auth; extracted hardcoded credentials (admin:superduperlooperpassword_lol) from JS source.

attack_path.technique: Decoding Obscure Encodings (Ook → Base64 → Zip Archive)
attack_path.result: Decoded Ook code in success.html revealing hidden path /asdiSIAJJ0QWE9JAS containing Base64-encoded zip archive.

attack_path.technique: Zip Password Cracking and Further Encoding Decoding (Hex → Base64 → Brainfuck)
attack_path.result: Cracked zip password 'password'; decoded contents to get Brainfuck code that revealed PlaySMS password 'idkwhatispass'.

attack_path.technique: PlaySMS Login and Remote Code Execution via CSV Import
attack_path.result: Logged into PlaySMS with admin:idkwhatispass; uploaded PHP reverse shell embedded in CSV via import.php; obtained www-data shell.

attack_path.technique: Privilege Escalation via SUID Binary and ROP Exploit
attack_path.result: Found SUID binary /home/ayush/.binary/rop with NX enabled but PIE and ASLR disabled; crafted ROP chain exploiting buffer overflow to get root shell.
Copied disk image and used photorec to recover rop.c source code; bash history revealed compilation flags (-m32 -fno-stack-protector -no-pie).
Ports 22 (SSH), 80 (Nginx HTTP), 9200 (Elasticsearch via Nginx proxy) discovered.
Queried Elasticsearch indices; found 'quotes' index with 253 entries in Spanish containing suspicious Base64 encoded strings.
Decoded base64 strings revealed SSH credentials: user 'security' with password 'spanish.is.key'.
Successfully logged in as user 'security' using discovered credentials.
Discovered Logstash Java process running as root; noted /etc/logstash/conf.d writable by kibana group.
Used local port forwarding to access Kibana; exploited LFI leading to Node.js reverse shell as kibana user.

attack_path.technique: Logstash Misconfiguration Exploitation for Root RCE
attack_path.result: Modified Logstash pipeline input file with command injection payload; Logstash executed it as root, yielding root shell.
Ports 22 (SSH), 80 (Apache HTTP), and 3000 (Node.js Express) discovered; /support directory found with HelpDeskZ 1.0.2.
Predicted MD5 hashed filename with epoch timestamp; uploaded PHP reverse shell to /support/uploads/tickets/; got shell as 'help' user.
Discovered user info via GraphQL: username 'helpme@helpme.com' and MD5 hashed password.
Cracked MD5 hash to plaintext password 'godhelpmeplz'.

attack_path.technique: Blind SQL Injection (HelpDeskZ 1.0.2 - 41200.py) via param[] array
attack_path.result: Extracted SHA1 hash of staff password via boolean-based blind SQLi.
Cracked SHA1 hash to plaintext password 'Welcome1'.
Logged in as 'helpme@helpme.com' using cracked password.
Discovered outdated kernel version 4.4.0-116-generic vulnerable to OverlayFS local root exploit.
Compiled and executed exploit; obtained root shell.
